content.description:
Climb the reddish face to the high first bolt. Move up and right to the base of a crack. Follow the crack up to the last bolt. Continue following the easier climbing to the anchors on top.

Beware of crossloading the carabiner on the 4th bolt.
Climb easy moves to a ledge, traverse, cross over One Move Oneder, then ascend to top.  Can get to anchors on One Move Oneder or First Communion.
content.protection: Standard rack. One fixed bolt from One Move Oneder can be used if necessary.

content.description: Work up a slab with a high first bolt to a ledge with an undercut bulge.  Techy face climbing brings you to the roof and crux.  The climbing eases off after the roof, ending with licheny edges.
content.protection: 7 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with leaver biners.
content.location: Near the far end of the Ninja wall, down through a split boulder and around the corner from the Black Hanger and Carpe Diem routes

content.description: Start in the corner, climb up to the ledge, up the crack on the left, and follow the ramp to the trees.
content.protection: .5 to 3, a #4 makes it less scary

content.description:
Shimmy your way of the low chimney up to the first bolt. Alternatively, you can make the slightly harder face and stemming moves up to the first bolt. Continue up the chimney to the base of the roof. Clip the bolt inside of the roof and the bolt on the roof with a should length runner. I recommend back cleaning the lower bolt to help avoid heinous rope drag at the crux.

Traverse out from under the roof on great holds out to the right. Pull the final move on blind hands to an odd stance to clip the anchors.

**Currently there is a hollow flake that is used at the lip of the roof to clip the anchors. This will come off one day. Highly recommend that this gets cleaned before this line sees more traffic.**
content.location: The obvious low chimney and large high roof just right of CU Rodeo.

content.description: Obvious crack directly to the left of the roof in the OG corner. Follow it all the way to the top. Rap down off a tree. Great moderate trad climb, eats gear.

climbs.name: Nick Fury
climbs.fa: Brian Brydges and Mike Gray, September 3, 2017

content.description: Start under the big roof and make moves on good holds to surmount the roof. Once above the roof move up and slightly right clipping the forth bolt. Move further right, on a mossy slab, to join with "The Nick of Time" on it's 3rd bolt.
content.protection: 7 bolts, chain anchors. Brings some longer slings to extend the anchor to avoid running the rope over an edge at the anchor.
content.location: Under the big roof to the right of the black hanger area.

climbs.name: Native Suns
climbs.fa: Steve Emswiler and Mike Gray, December 28, 2016

content.description: Start in a short corner and climb up to a crack, and the first bolt. Move up to another crack and then left to a huge jug, easier for folks with a larger wingspan. Then mantle onto the ledge. From here the route switches to delicate face climbing to the top, becoming slightly more overhung as you get closer to the anchors.

Thin edges disguised by loads of lichen make this a decent climb, but a bit hard to find the 5.7 holds. Start in a bit of a chimney, work your way past a bolt on the right side wall and up to a ledge with a 2nd bolt. Continue on a vertical face to the anchors.
content.location: On the main trail traversing the base of the Ninja wall, past Dread Skills, but before the trail rounds the corner to Defenders of the Faith

climbs.name: In The Nick Of Time
climbs.fa: Brian Brydges and Michael Gray, August 25, 2017

content.description: Start on the face with big holds then pull into a right facing dihedral. Enjoy some stemming on your way of the the final bulge before the anchors.
Very nice face climbing up big pockets and neat features. A very fun route, quality is only marred by the ledge after bolt 2.
content.location: Hike climber's right past the Hawk arête until you see a stretch of near vertical wall. The rightmost line of bolts is hummingbird.

content.description: Climb the ledge to approach. Start directly right of the roof. Climb up to the ledge, and follow the crack up the top. Move left at the top to get up to the trees. Lower off a tree at the top. Dirty but fun climbing
A nice mix of arête, crack, roof, and face climbing. Multiple 5.9 sections make this pretty sustained for the grade.
content.protection: 6 bolts. A small-medium nut can protect the moves going to the high-ish first bolt. Shoulder length runners is recommended for bolt 3.
content.location: Continue climbers right past CU Rodeo until you see the prominent bolted arête and roof.

content.description: Climb the arete left of "Super K Meets The Punisher". Use a long draw on the first & last bolt. Finishing at the anchors at the right of the chimney
content.location: Climb the Arete at the left of the chimney.

content.description: Slab climb past a high first bolt to a ledge, then launch into a tightly-bolted crux section of laybacking.  Stay right on the arete.
content.protection: 7 bolts.  2 bolt anchor with chains and quicklinks (rusty as of 04-2019)
content.location: Just downhill and around the corner from Carpe Diem

content.description: About 15 feet of Hawk, climb up 5.8 / 5.9 terrain with a couple of good rests to a 5.10- roof pull followed by easy moves to the chains.
Climb dusty slab up to a ledge with a pod and and a high first bolt.  Enter steep terrain with incut seams and juggy edges, cranking through the crux roof to a thin slab to the anchors.
content.protection: 6 bolts.  Two bolt anchor with cold shuts.
content.location: At the end of the Ninja Wall trail

content.description:
Pull through a reachy start to reach a horizontal break at the first bolt (stick clip highly recommended).

Crank a boulder problem that has no place on an 11d/12a route and continue up easier, unremarkable climbing for the next 30 feet.

Given 4 stars and an 11+ rating in the guidebook -- the crux would not be out of place on a 12+ route, but given the much easier climbing afterwards (5.10-) I would assume the developer took the "average" difficulty into consideration as opposed to single moves.

Rock quality is better than most of the area.
content.location: One of the first climbs on Ninja Wall when coming from the approach trail.

content.description:
Fantastic movement, stone, and exposure! Fun moves up a pocketed face bring you to a ledge. The bolt position on the roof indicates you're meant to climb straight up and over - which is the crux - instead of skirting off to the right side where there are slightly better holds and remnants of an old bolt hanger.  Should you choose to go right, the climb goes at 10-, whereas pulling the roof directly feels more like 10+ (or perhaps 11- for folks with 5-8 or less wingspan) and involves a rather blind reach.

Extending the draw right at the roof makes for less drag, but also a potentially worse fall, so choose accordingly.

Not recommended for budding 5.10 leaders.
content.protection: 6 bolts. Small to medium nuts or cams to protect between bolts three and four.
content.location: Continue right past hummingbird until you see a ramp leading up to a small platform. There are two lines here - the left route being a red tagged project, and the right, starting over some large chossy boulders laying about on the ledge is Carpe Diem.

content.description: Good face holds leads to an interesting crux pulling over the prow to a nice finger crack and more face holds to the anchor.

Cautiously climb up easy hold on some slightly loose rock to a great set of holds and your first bolt. Work up the technical crux to a couple of jugs and your second bolt. Continue up great hands and delicate feet to a core engaging clipping hold for your third bolt. Pull onto the ledge on good holds, be careful not to reach deep onto the ledge to avoid the loose rock and vegetation.

Take a well deserved rest and work up the delicate face past 2 bolts to the anchors. Over the last two bolts, keep the bolts in the center of your body for full value. Working left of the bolts eases the climb a little and make an awkward reach to clip the anchors.

Ledge fall potential between bolt 4 and 5.
content.location: Pass the obvious chimney of Quasimodo and the arete of Hawk to a vertical wall with red on the rock down low.

content.description: On the other side of the arete from Hobbgrobblin. Climb the ramp to the base of the crack, follow to the top, move to the right. Descend by rappelling off a tree. Mostly listing this route so nobody else will be tempted to try it, it sucks. Mostly scrambling with a 5-foot section of fun chimney climbing.
content.protection: Standard rack and a #4 will do it, wide stuff would allow for better protection but not needed
